title: Will SpaceX and/or Virgin Galactic complete a successful space tourist flight before 1 January 2022?

Already done for SpaceX, Timeline too short for virgin

Successful launch, leaving 1% possibility that something goes wrong with the landing in a few days which makes it not count as "successful" but overall looks very likely to resolve as only SpaceX.
I'm actually think it's 98%, but hedging my previous lower estimates.

El tema que abarca esta pregunta esta sin lugar a dudas en boca de todos. Él solo pensar en poder recorrer el espacio como un "turista" (sin ser astronauta) y de manera continua, es algo que parece tan lejano pero al mismo tiempo algo que podría suceder en cualquier momento. Pero, ¿SpaceX o Virgin Galactic lograran este cometido?. SpaceX en el ultimo tiempo a logrado grandes avances en la exploración espacial privada. Entre los principales logros, fue la primera empresa privada en tener un cohete en la órbita espacial y también fue la primera empresa privada en llevar astronautas a la ISS (Estación Espacial Internacional) con el cohete Crew Dragon (noviembre 2020). Otro gran logro que ha cosechado su dueño, Elon Musk, es concretar un contrato millonario con la NASA y formar una alianza que hasta ahora no ha tenido problemas. También con la alianza formada con la NASA, cumplió el deseo de esta de llevar de vuelta al espacio astronautas estadounidenses y no depender de cohetes rusos. Por otro lado, Virgin Galactic realizo un vuelo exitoso a la órbita terrestre con su fundador, Richard Branson, el 11 de julio. Sin embargo, su gran lista de fracasos a puesto en duda la seguridad y confianza que transmiten a sus futuros usuarios. Adicionalmente, la incertidumbre de un posible fracaso en algún vuelo de prueba para el vuelo comercial solo a provocado una continua caída en las acciones de la empresa. Es por esto que pongo todas mis fichas en SpaceX, que ademas anuncio de manera oficial, a principio de año, que realizaría un viaje comercial en el ultimo trimestre de 2021 con la misión Inspiration4. Ademas, los pasajeros que abordaran esta misión serán sorteados en un concurso para cualquier habitante de EE.UU mayor de 18 años, generando una gran expectación.
Everything seems to be on track for Inspiration4 & SpaceX: https://twitter.com/SpaceX/status/1436489773691113480
What the heck, lets go all in
Inspiration4 launches in a few days, I'd guess about a 4% chance of failure from my perception of SpaceX's falcon track record.

Not sure what I’m missing, being so divergent with the crowd forecast. 
1. There’s a tonne of activity with space tourism right now. 
E.g.:
Virgin Galactic expects to complete the remaining test flights by early fall or late summer. They aim to fly researchers and tourists into space from 2022. Currently, it looks like the company has everything going as per plan. 
https://www.nasdaq.com/articles/virgin-galactic-is-ready-for-the-race-to-space-2021-06-28 2. It’s not exactly groundbreaking:
“The first space tourist was US millionaire Dennis Tito, who in 2001 paid $20 million to hitch a ride on a Russian Soyuz spacecraft to visit the international space station and spent eight days there.”  There then were 7 other space tourists after Tito.  Blue Origin is making the headlines because “this is the first time that space tourism will be attempted by a private company.” https://www.thehindubusinessline.com/opinion/columns/slate/all-you-wanted-to-know-about/article34814909.ece Also FTA: “Space tourism may seem like an outlandish concept today. But don’t forget air travel for leisure was considered equally improbable a little more than a century ago.” 3. Inspiration4 is still scheduled for 15 September: https://spaceflightnow.com/launch-schedule/
That’s a lot of time, even with Musk’s alleged propensity to miss deadlines, to have a delay and still complete the flight this year.  4 Per clarifications, “A non-commercial suborbital flight with only Virgin Galactic personnel, including founders and employees, aboard the spacecraft would not count.”

https://www.digitaltrends.com/news/spacexs-first-space-tourism-astronauts-show-off-their-suits/
“ Training for September’s mission has been underway for several months and has included a ride in a centrifuge at the National Aerospace Training and Research Center in Pennsylvania to experience launch-like G-forces, and a hike up Washington’s Mount Rainier designed to enhance crew teamwork.”

Virgin Galactic has announced it will not launch tourists into space this year.  As regards SpaceX, the date for the Inspiration 4 mission has been planned for 15 September which gives quite a lot of leeway before the end of the year.  I had originally estimated 38% based in a 'Q4' planned launch date and 1 month leeway.  Also the crew have now been selected and I have found no evidence that there are any delays with preparations yet.  A further crewed mission was launched on 24 April (albeit not with private citizens)
Virgin I think is too far behind schedule but adding a small chance in case they move ahead of schedule after recent successful test.

Updating slightly upwards for VG, after the successful test flight of May 22 [1] (h/t @Eliac). But I agree with @SE_Meyer that VG still has a lot of road in front of them (at least two more test flights before the end of the year) before being able to going fully commercial. --------------------------------

Two more test flights with VG employees and the Rich himself, before an Italian Air Force mission will be the first booked crew after FAA licensing. While the next two may happen in 2021, as everything seems to be on track now and worked well, these wouldn't count as per 05 April 2021 clarification. The latter one would count, as per 05 May 2021 clarification, but it may not happen before 2022, since licensing is essential, and the FAA will have to analyse whether all faults and issues with the VSS2 have been successfully handled, before it's getting clearance for a true touristic mission.
More success on SpaceX technology, no evidence of change at Virgin...

The three men are paying $55 million each to spend eight days at the orbiting outpost, according to SpaceX." https://www.nbcnews.com/science/space/jeff-bezos-blue-origin-auction-seat-space-tourism-flight-rcna828
"And Elon Musk's SpaceX will launch a billionaire and his sweepstakes winners in September. That will be followed by a flight by three businessmen to the International Space Station in January." https://www.ctvnews.ca/sci-tech/60-years-since-1st-american-in-space-tourists-lining-up-1.5414659

SpaceX has a scheduled launch for Inspiration4 on Sep 15 [4]. The company has had some real successes lately, but this will be a first-time-ever attempt, so I will stay conservative to 50-50. I'm not worried about a good score, more a greater ability to predict.

No revisions (no new information to alter forecasts). Anecdotally, my sense is SpaceX may be more probable but will wait on firmer data to change forecasts.

It was difficult to establish a base rate. However finally I decided to use the time gaps between the Space Shuttle launches of the Challenger space shuttle (reusable spacecraft + space launches).  SpaceX:
For spaceX I tried to determine what is the probability they will make it in 8.5 months since the "Resilience" crew dragon comes back from its first flight. I added 6 months to each time gap of the Challenger spaceflight assuming it will take 1/4 of time to prepare the civilians (for typical astronaut it takes 2 years). Hence I got 33.33% of the challenger flights being less than 8.5 months therefore I will be using it as my "external perspective". Virgin Galactic:
I took the same data however thanks to the article by @smingers I decided to look into whether VG actually has an FAA license and if not what would they need to get it. So I found that they don't have it and according to https://www.hindustantimes.com/travel/vss-unity-richard-branson-s-space-tourism-firm-virgin-galactic-unveils-space-plane-s-cabin-poised-for-commercial-flights/story-QFnw9y1rC0zSvjzTvzXVoM.html (although this source is a bit outdated) we can assume that they would need 3 - 4 flights with 4 passengers until they will get it. Considering the fact that they were also expecting the commercial program to start in 2022 (https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/26/virgin-galactic-spce-falls-after-test-delays-push-back-tourism-service.html) I decided to go for 4 flights for FAA. Based on this I took challenger time gaps between missions multiplied all of them by 4. Hence I found that 11.11% of challenger programs were below 9 months (yes VG has 0.5 months more). Some problems:
- Further "Internal perspective" investigation required for both companies to modify the base rates to suit current situation
- I was unable to figure out how to compare capabilities of SpaceX in 2020 vs NASA in 1983 - 1986. They do have less employees, but also less space shuttles and projects to deal with (although just an assumption)
- I had to ignore my previous forecast as I forgot to do the external perspective first
- Sadly I am breaking the principle of small updates (sadly greater than 3.5%) however I had to basically redo my forecast from the beginning to do it properly (find the base rate)

However, in late February, Virgin Galactic Holdings Inc. announced that it has postponed test flights for its rocket-powered spaceflight program for two months in order to address technical issues, further delaying its promise of commercial flights.  The company now expects that “Unity will begin flying private astronauts” in early 2022 – which will mark the beginning of its commercial space tourism service.  https://www.cnbc.com/2021/02/26/virgin-galactic-spce-falls-after-test-delays-push-back-tourism-service.html The SpaceX spacecraft planned for its first commercial mission is SpaceX’s Starship.  Starship hasn’t had great luck with its recent test flights; the most recent one just took place on March 3, and though it landed successfully, it exploded on the landing pad shortly after. The two preceding rockets exploded on contact, so it does seem there’s been some improvement.  https://singularityhub.com/2021/03/04/applications-are-open-for-a-free-trip-to-the-moon-on-a-spacex-rocket/

SpaceX currently has four private missions scheduled for the coming years:
    - Inspiration 4 (2021, low orbit, Dragon)
    - Axiom Space (early 2022, ISS, Dragon)
    - Space Adventures (late 2022, low orbit, Dragon)
    - Maezawa Moon mission (2023, Moon, Starship) Given that the moon mission was originally scheduled for 2018, and considering that this mission is the most complex, there is a clear timeline with milestones to be met.  SpaceX has continued to meet milestones over the past year (ISS May 2020, Dragon). Due to technical issues, Virgin Galactic has recently delayed its first space tourism mission to 2022. Dragon spacecraft is flight-ready therefore recent Starship crashes are unlikely to have near term effects on the SpaceX timeline. The key aspects I'm considering are regulatory constraints, safety and engineering issues, relative priority of tourist launches to other competing operations, and track record of meeting stated mission timelines. @MCJNDU has an excellent baseline assessment. He makes the point that SpaceX consistently met timelines for getting to the ISS. I would suggest however that a civilian space flight has somewhat less priority assigned to it than a mission undertaken jointly with NASA and the immense reputational costs of failing under that scenario. That's not to say there aren't strong incentives to be first in a lucrative market. Given the SpaceX stated goal of a civilian mission no earlier than the 4th Quarter of 2021 and Virgin Galactic's recent failures, it seems SpaceX is the only company with a realistic shot. I assume a high likelihood the timeline will slip, but 1 in 4 for SpaceX seems about right.

23.02.2021 SX (SpaceX):
Technical aspect:
- Crew dragon “resilience” seems to be functional as was able to accomplish “Crew-1” successfully
- Falcon9 launch vehicle had no failures during launches (from what I can see here: https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/List_of_Falcon_9_first-stage_boosters#Block_5 ) 
Conclusion: technical aspect is fully ready hence has a high probability of accomplishing the Inspiration4 mission Organisational aspect:
- space missions “Crew-2” and “Crew-3” have to be completed before without damaging the crew dragon resilience
Conclusion: I consider that the probability of each mission being successful is 0.9. We have to wait and see what will happen in reality. If the crew dragon “resilience” will get damaged or destroyed the new spacecraft will have to be used for Inspiration4 Crew:
- Full list to be announced on math 1st
- Maybe an outdated source, but standard astronaut training requires 2 years (https://www.nasa.gov/audience/forstudents/5-8/features/F_Astronauts_in_Training.html). ASSUMPTION: it is possible to that less training might be needed (compared to a standard astronaut) because they are not exiting into space or performing any additional missions; only need to know how to pilot the spacecraft (although this can be a wrong assumption)
- ASSUMPTION: if only one pilot is needed than Jared Isacmen might require less time to prepare as he is an experienced pilot of both military and civilian aircraft (https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Jared_Isaacman#Aerobatics_career )
- As was noted by @MCJNDU “Launch no earlier than Q4” (see: https://inspiration4.com/mission) doesn’t sound to confident for SX. I am assuming that the likelihood that the deadline will be beyond 2021 increases. 
Conclusion: Not fully confident in this one. Still assuming this one is their weakest point. Commitment:
- ASSUMPTION: Both Jared Isacmen and Elon Musk must have a relatively strong commitment because one have payed a large sum of money for the flight while the other must uphold the reputation of SpaceX while also competing with BlueOrigin and VG
Conclusion: Just an assumption. Anyone of them can pull out if they will feel threatened. Same goes for crew members and possible postponing of flight.

Key questions considered: LOCATIONS/WX:  Where are the launches from and are there any better/worse months historically for launching space vehicles? -- SpaceX operates in 4 locations in CA, FL, and TX.  Weather causes delays, but historically SpaceX has launched every quarter of the year especially since 2017.   VG operates primarily in 2 locations in CA and NM, of which NM provides the harsher conditions.  I couldn't find good launch data by quarter for VG but assume with their launch platform that weather and annual climate that all months of the year are equally good for launch possibilities.   https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/File:SpaceX_launches_timeline.png
PAX:  Have passengers expressed interests?  -- Yes, for both, in healthy numbers of willing payers/participants.
PRECEDENCE:   Have both companies accomplished flight at 50miles up? -- Yes.
LEGAL:  Are there legal hurdles that could prevent tourism in space?  -- Yes, but both companies seem to have measures in place already that overcome legal hurdles, or are expected to get soon (e.g. VG expects FAA license w/i next 2 flights).   This site provides an overview on the legality of tourism:  https://www.spacelegalissues.com/space-law-space-tourism-legal-aspects/.  "The law applicable to space tourism is very diversified and subject to two main criteria: the first, rationae loci, linked to the place where transport is provided (airspace or outer space); the second, rationae materiae, is linked to the means of transport."  Both companies appear to already have in place the necessary legal instruments in place to go forth, to include a lengthy consent process for passengers.
EXPECTATIONS:  How futures stock prices impact?  -- Both companies stock prices and futures are doing great, leading company leadership to push forward aggressively to reach ROI goals.
REALITY:  Both companies have a history of delays, however, SpaceX appears to have met more of its stated goals/ambitions.  In particular, VG stated in 2008 that sub-orbital spaceflight for tourists would happen in "18 months".  A 2014 crash delayed progress too.  SpaceX seems to be more reliable/innovative in meeting timelines.
COMPETITION:  SpaceX / VG and even Amazon??? competition of meeting 2021 expectations, I think, will drive completion of tourist space flight in 2021.  However, with the history of delays for nearly every milestone ever set by both companies and the goal being 4Q2021, I can see this slipping into 2022.  But, if 1 company meets this goal, I believe the other company will be hard-pressed to claim a similar victory and thus also meet the goal.  If only 1 company meets the goal, SpaceX appears to be more geared towards success based off of past 3 years momentum.

I haven't really paid much attention to this endeavor so this research is entirely new to me. I'm impressed that the technology seems to already exist.  At this point, it really seems the major hurdle is obtaining government approval. From https://www.cnbc.com/2020/09/26/space-tourism-how-spacex-virgin-galactic-blue-origin-axiom-compete.html - Virgin Galactic has already sold about tickets to about 600 passengers at a price between $200,000 and $250,000 each, although the company expects it could increase its prices substantially for the first commercial flights.  To date Virgin Galactic has flown five people to space on two test flights. All five are company employees, with four pilots controlling the spacecraft and chief astronaut trainer Beth Moses riding along as a test passenger on the second flight. - In the summer of 2020, SpaceX, with its Falcon 9 rocket and Crew Dragon capsule, entered the orbital tourism arena. This summer SpaceX launched and returned two NASA astronauts with its spacecraft for the first time ever, in a mission that was historic for both Musk’s company and the U.S. space agency.   SpaceX had already signed two separate agreements with companies looking to fly private paying passengers to space. While NASA’s astronauts spend months up at the ISS, the private missions will be only about 10 days at most. Initial research seems to indicate that Virgin Galactic is further along.  However, their space vehicle suffered some setbacks on a launch that was supposed to occur in early February.  Unity's first two spaceflights, in December 2018 and February 2019, took off from California's Mojave Air and Space Port, near the headquarters of Virgin Galactic's manufacturing subsidiary, The Spaceship Company. But the upcoming third flight will lift off from Spaceport America in New Mexico, Virgin Galactic's commercial hub. It will be the first crewed space mission ever to launch from the state.  Unity has already tried once to make spaceflight number three. But the space plane's rocket motor failed to fire properly during that first attempt, on Dec. 12, 2020, and pilots C.J. Sturckow and Dave Mackay brought Unity down for a premature but safe landing at Spaceport America. (SpaceShipTwo takes off beneath the wings of a carrier plane, then makes its own way to suborbital space after being dropped at an altitude of about 50,000 feet, or 15,000 meters.)  https://www.space.com/virgin-galactic-spaceshiptwo-unity-third-spaceflight-delay So my initial feeling is that SpaceX seems in the 8% likelihood, Virgin Galactic a bit higher, like maybe 27.  Since both cannot be higher than any of the others (conjunction fallacy), I'll put Yes, both at 5%.  Therefore, no takes the remaining percentage. Checking the "wisdom of the crowd" I'm really surprised to see that SpaceX is higher than what I suspected.  I'll read some of the comments and see if I can be convinced by the crowd.  I like the comments put forth by @MCJNDU and @ml2021, but I'm not willing to go as high as they are.  However, I will adjust my numbers accordingly to go with the crowd. - SpaceX seems in the 23% likelihood, Virgin Galactic 15%.  Since both cannot be higher than any of the others (conjunction fallacy), I'll put Yes, both at 10%.  The rest goes to no.

Tough to baseline this one. SpaceX has a civilian launched planned before the end of 2021 using the Falcon 9 rocket and Dragon capsule they have successfully used with astronauts twice in 2020. Virgin Galactic had to reschedule its Dec 2020 launch and seems to be behind SpaceX as @MCJNDU pointed out. The probability that both would successfully put civilians in space in 2021 is pretty low. Would need to update this forecast as SpaceX's proposed launch date approaches.

It’s difficult to establish a base rate for this forecast as only one company has completed successful space-tourism flights.  In 2001, MirCorp, a Russian spaceflight company, ferried the first space tourist to the international space station abord a Soyuz spacecraft.  Russia has conducted manned launches onboard Soyuz rockets since 1968.  The delay between their first successful manned flight and first space tourist flight was regulatory in nature, not technological.  For SpaceX and Virgin Galactic, the opposite is true. The 2004 Commercial Space Launch Amendments Act effectively removed any legal impediments to space tourism through 2023, allowing the industry to go through a “learning period” before imposing legislation (https://crsreports.congress.gov/product/pdf/R/R46500).  Currently, U.S. companies need only receive FAA certification before beginning space tourism flights.  Once SpaceX and/or Virgin Galactic receive FAA certification, very little regulation stands between them and their first tourist flight. The best indication of whether either company will ferry tourists into space in 2021 is to see how their actual progress compares to their proposed timelines. In December 2018, after a successful test flight, Virgin Galactic announced an aggressive timeline for their first space-tourist flight.  Virgin’s plan was to establish a launch facility in New Mexico by early 2019 and begin commercial flights by mid-2019.  Virgin Galactic aborted their first attempted launch from the NM facility in December 2020 after the aircraft’s primary rocket failed to ignite.  The launch was rescheduled for 13 February 2021 but canceled three days prior due to “technical issues” discovered during pre-launch checks.  This puts Virgin about two years behind their initially proposed timeline.  Virgin still needs to complete two test flights before earning the required FAA certifications for commercial space flight.  At their current pace of one successful test flight every 26 months (December 2018 to present), Virgin Galactic will not complete required testing for FAA certification until 2023.  I assess Virgin Galactic’s likelihood of success in 2021 at only 5%. SpaceX plans to ferry tourists on its Dragon spacecraft, which has already received FAA certification.  Despite some delays between tests, SpaceX consistently met its milestones leading up to its first ISS mission on 2 March 2019.  In a 1 February 2021 statement, SpaceX said their first all-civilian mission will take place “no earlier than the fourth quarter [2021].”  While SpaceX has proven its ability to meet its milestones, the caveat “no earlier than” does not express strong confidence SpaceX will complete a tourist flight before the end of 2021.  Of note, SpaceX has several launches already scheduled throughout 2021, but has not scheduled this mission with NASA, the European Space Agency, or Roscosmos (the Russian Corporation for Space Activities) https://www.space.com/32286-space-calendar.html.  This is likely a further indication that SpaceX is unsure of its ability to meet a 2021 deadline.  I assess SpaceX’s likelihood of success in 2021 at 40%. Rather than sold for profit, seats aboard SpaceX’s proposed first all-civilian flight will be awarded to St. Jude’s Children’s Research Hospital employees and donors.  I plan to request clarification from GJO whether this meets the definition of “tourist” since these passengers are traveling for pleasure but not necessarily paying for the service.

Note: I’m classifying civilians who fly to space, even if they receive training on how to be a crewmember, as tourists, if they paid for the space flight. SpaceX has inspiration 4 scheduled with a civilian crew (I consider them tourists) for October 2021. Considering that spaceX has successfully flown the Crew Dragon capsule a few times now, I’m estimating an 80% chance that mission stays on schedule. Virgin Galactic has three flights scheduled, first an uncrewed test, then one with employees, and the third with Richard Branson. For these purposes, I consider him a tourist, not a crewmember. Based on technical issues they have had and schedule issues, I’m estimating a 40% chance of VG putting a tourist in orbit this year. Thus, my split is as follows: 32% for both, 8% for just Virgin, 48% for just SpaceX, and 12% for no launch.

While both are technically capable of this feat, I do not think that they will receive authorization to take a civilian into space as per the definition in the question. Manned flights will happen, but not a tourist flight.
The fact that Virgin Galactic hasn't even left the ground, coupled with the fact that the parent company's stock has not seen the kind of significant spikes that SpaceX, Tesla, etc. has.

SpaceX announced on Monday that it will launch four private individuals on a Crew Dragon capsule into orbit around the Earth, dubbed “the world’s first all-civilian mission.” It is scheduled to launch in the fourth quarter of 2021.

Both companies have historically set ambitious targets and failed to meet self-imposed timelines. Virgin Galactic seems focused on sub-orbital flights, but has had one fatal crash, and several technical issues that have delayed its goal of achieving commercial space tourism by 3+ years (originally 2018). SpaceX's goal is more ambitious, given the all-civilian crew, whose space-readiness training could take longer than anticipated, particularly given the human and PR risks of sending non-astronauts into space. However, SpaceX seems to have better technical capabilities than VG. So, overall: highest probability that neither will do it by Jan 1 '22. But if one of them does do it, it's a higher probability that SpaceX can, and the lowest probability that both VG and SpaceX do it.

I don't have a great base rate for this, but there are a few things that I'm weighing on this.  First, SpaceX is the only company to come out and say they're planning to get a civilian mission into space this year (https://www.nbcnews.com/science/space/spacex-announces-first-mission-space-all-civilian-crew-n1256390). Then again, they're aiming at the fourth quarter of this year AND it's Elon Musk saying it - nothing against the man, he's a hell of an entrepreneur and certainly a bulldog when it comes to those things he believes in, but he's also known to be fairly bullish on his timelines. I believe he believes it pays to light fires under folks' butts (and rockets! Ha!), so he tends to push aggressive timelines. Add to that the fact that COVID is still running around adding uncertainty to the playing field, and I think we have added downward pressure on their likelihood of launching in time.  As far as I can tell Virgin isn't even planning to put its civilian mission up this year. Seems like a pretty unlikely shot. I'm thinking it's SpaceX or nobody, and nobody's in the lead (though again, I don't count Elon out!)

Both companies have in the past successfully flown people above 50miles. So they are technically capable, and have said they plan to fly tourists. so the question is will this happen in 2021. Haven't done the full homework for a base rate on each company but I think we'd need to know how often they meet their published timelines. first brush says spaceX (or at least Mr. Musk) is overly optimistic https://www.cnn.com/2019/05/02/tech/elon-musk-predictions/index.html
ditto for virgin galactic. We'd also want to know what usually drives the delays so we could tell throughout the year if delay looks more or less likely. I think that Virgin Galactic's test flights in the first quarter of the year will be a big indicator for their odds. Given that SpaceX is the only one of the two with a published plan to fly tourists in 2021 and it isn't until the end of 2021 I can see a lot of things that might delay it. Something as mundane as bad weather is a factor.

SpaceX wants to launch a tourism flight in Q4 and its capsule is ready as is the launch vehicle. Virgin Galactic is still in the testing phase - so behind SpaceX.  Timing risk is very real given the complexity of these launch vehicles and safety risks. SpaceX could easily slip by months - especially considering the trip is intended as fund raising trip for St. Judes.  Launching supply missions to the ISS and satellite launches will likely take priority over using launch vehicles for tourism flights.

SpaceX seems pretty set on doing this, they placed a SuperBowl ad for spots in the flight, they have an established track record of successful missions and have sent humans to space before, I think there's a good likelihood they pull it off. That said their official website says "no earlier than 4th quarter of this year" so that leaves open the possibility for delay. https://www.spacex.com/updates/inspiration-4-mission/index.html Virgin seems to have a track record of mishaps with their vehicle and no concrete timeline, so I'm skeptical it's something that happens this year. Their last test didn't reach space because the engines didn't fire once the passenger vehicle detached. Based on that I'm assuming SpaceX is likely, Virgin pretty unlikely, and also a 40% possibility that both miss their timelines.
I doubt this is doable in 2021
Recent crash and follow-up dampen likelihood of space tourist launch within time frame.
People are more motivated than ever to get off the planet.
They have probed they can safely take humans to space.
Its life Jim, but not as we know it

* Virgin
	+ hopes to start with commercial flights in 2021
	- Virgin Galactic predicted beginning of commercial service by mid-2020 and was wrong
	- Virgin Galactic has incentives to be too optimistic
	- In Dec 12, they had severe technical issues on a test flight
	- COVID has interfered with earlier test flights
	- they plan two more test flights and a flight with Branson (which is supposed to kick off commercial operation) before starting commercial operations
	- Predictions about when innovative technology will be ready often tend to be too optimistic rather than too pessimistic, in particular when made by those working on the technologies. * SpaceX
	+ hopes to go end of 2021 (announced Feb 1st)
	+ have concrete plans for the mission (people who will fly are already determined, ...)
	+ the company has had successes in other areas of spaceflight
	o incentives to be too optimistic maybe a bit weaker than for Virgin Galactic (not publicly traded)
	- COVID might interfere.
	- Predictions about when innovative technology will be ready often tend to be too optimistic rather than too pessimistic, in particular when made by those working on the technologies.
Launch dates get moved all the time for many reasons, the window for this launch is now less than 330 days.
Both companies have made the necessary technological advancements to achieve this.
